thread.title: Cystic Fibrosis: Matthias Fuchs raises money in Qantas marathon
thread.title_full: Cystic Fibrosis: Matthias Fuchs raises money in Qantas marathon

author: Rowena Ryan
title: Cystic Fibrosis: Matthias Fuchs raises money in Qantas marathon
text:
Matthias Fuchs, left, on his last flying marathon.
Rowena Ryan Escape FOR most people, this sounds utterly crazy. Spending 12 days flying to every continent (except Antarctica) on 16 flights, only ever leaving a plane for a quick layover at the airport.
But for Sydney businessman Matthias Fuchs, 47, it’s a crazy challenge with a special message.
On 2 November, Fuchs will begin a flying marathon to raise money and awareness for cystic fibrosis, Fuchs’ 13-year-old daughter Kristen has cystic fibrosis.
Spending almost 200 hours in the air, travelling 167,000km, the trip will include six Pacific Ocean crossings and four Indian Ocean crossings. He will take just carry-on luggage and for 12 consecutive days will eat, sleep, live and breathe on planes.
For Fuchs, flying is a lifelong obsession. He has recorded every single flight he has been on since he was born — an incredible 1232 flights, which equates to around one flight every 10 days.
“As a pilot friend of mine said, I’ve got more flying time than a first officer in a 747,” says Fuchs, who has previously completed this challenge in 2011 and 2013, but never for this length of time.
Matthias Fuchs and his daughter, Kristen, 13, who has cystic fibrosis. Source: Supplied
The jaw-dropping flight schedule includes flights from Sydney to Singapore return, Sydney to Los Angeles return, Sydney to Johannesburg return and 10 other routes, and have all been donated free of charge from Qantas.
Most of his schedule allows only a few hours layover between flights, however, Fuchs does have a day to spend in the airport at Tokyo, London and Los Angeles, where he can stretch his legs and take advantage of the airport lounge to refresh.
“The hardest stopover is always London, as you’re hanging around in the day when you’re body is saying go to sleep. Tokyo and LA are not so bad,” he says.
So what are the biggest challenges of flying solidly for 12 days straight?
“The one thing I find the most challenging is the habit of airlines to immediately close the blinds on a day flight, it means I’m permanently in darkness,” says Fuchs.
He also has to inject himself daily with Clexane to avoid Deep Vein Thrombosis, drink lots of fluid and he limits alcohol to around one or two wines a day.
“To not take precautions would be silly,” he says.
Matthias’ massive flight routes are mapped out. Source: Supplied
Surprisingly, Fuchs says the biggest benefit is that there is no jet lag.
“Your body doesn’t stop in different time zones long enough so it naturally reverts back to Sydney time, no matter where you are,” says Fuchs, who manages an average of only four hours sleep a day on the challenge.
This daunting fact has attracted the attention of one of the world’s leading sleep professors, Professor Ron Grunstein, who will use Fuchs as a type of “guinea pig”. He will wear a fitbit and have swabs of his cheeks taken everyday to assess the impact of sleep and how the body changes.
Fuchs says he has a military routine when it comes to flying. He has his earplugs ready to go and makes sure he boards early to snag a spot for his cabin luggage.
When possible he tries to book the bulk head seat in the front row so he can put his feet up on the wall, he likes a window during day flights and an aisle for overnight.
As for his family, “they think I’m mad of course”, he says, whose wife meets him during the challenge at Sydney airport with fresh shirts and underwear.
Fuchs has so far raised $130,000 with all funds going directly to the Cystic Fibrosis Unit at the Children’s Hospital at Westmead. His target is $150-$200K which would fund a part-time researcher for two years to continue to improve treatment efficiency. His two previous challenges raised a combined total of $270,000. The public can donate to his cause on his dedicated page .
Cystic Fibrosis is the most common life threatening recessive gene condition. It attacks the lungs and digestive system with repeated infections leading to lung damage and eventually respiratory failure.
